Fact Check Friday: Will wearing a mask increase the amount of carbon dioxide I breathe and make me sick?

No. For many years, health care providers have worn masks for extended periods of time with no adverse health reactions. The @CDC recommends wearing cloth masks while in public, and this option is very breathable. In healthy adults, there is no risk of hypoxia (lower oxygen levels). Carbon dioxide will freely flow out of your mask as you breathe.

If you feel uncomfortable in your mask, try to limit talking and breathe through your nose. That will reduce the humidity level in your mask. Also, try to take mask breaks throughout the day when you are able to move away from others.

We know this isn‚Äôt always easy and we appreciate all Vermonters have done to keep each other safe.

From Mayo Clinic Health System

At Hannaford, we're committed to helping you and your families to say safe and healthy during this challenging time. We've implemented extensive social distancing practices and other safeguards in our stores.

We need your help too, in keeping the number of customers shopping our stores or, in some instances, the number waiting to get into the supermarket to a minimum.

Please shop alone or with as few others as absolutely necessary. Make one larger trip, rather than several smaller ones. Try to visit the store during off-hours. Our busiest times are from 4-6 p.m. weekdays, Saturday mornings and early afternoon Sundays. We also are busy when stores first open daily. By shopping off-hours, you are helping us to maintain social distance between customers, and also with associates.

Working together, we will make the community safer, during this health crisis and beyond.

Teachers will be creating remote learning opportunities for each week we are out of school and calling each family weekly to check on progress and answer any questions.

This is a new journey for all of us. We thank you for your patience as we navigate this new territory!
